The reason this is such an excellent movie is because it is so beautifully written, and this is entirely the fault of the renowned novelist Robert James Waller, author of Bridges of Madison County. A loving protagonist, a talented woman with a secretive history, are swept up by a charismatic antagonist, and after a few exciting episodes (mostly thrilling and suspenseful) alternating with scenes that show the endearing side of the villain, she leaves her impotent partner for the antagonist, who, despite being bad, understands her better than anyone else. Elements of the movie are dedicate to time-tested storytelling, not even the stalwart performance of Scott Glenn as the villain, not the luscious Giovanna Zacarías as Luz, and not even the dedicated performance of Harvey Keitel as the CIA specialist assigned to track the villain down, can detract from its rich cultural background.

Goodnight, Mister Tom begins in an idyllic village in the south of England where the sun always seems to shine. There is abundant period feel in the village and more in London, including the ambulances rattling around. The soundtrack was cringeworthy and the message was heavy-handed and predictable. It's still bothers me and I struggle to articulate why I disliked it. I try to avoid thinking about it.

This disgusting spectacle was banned from American movie houses in the 1930s due to Hedy Lamarr's indecent exposure. A sordid tale of Hedy Lamarr revolves around the shameless Eva Hermann who is pressured into marrying an older man. She endures a ceremony that she finds distasteful and begins her life married to a man who find her unwelcome in his bed. He spends his time focusing on trivial matters, and in her desperation, she strips naked and plunges into the lake, disregarding the potential shock to unsuspecting onlookers. Her indecent exposure is brought to the attention of a passer

After hearing so much about the Church of Jesus Christ of the Latter Day Saints, I decided I would go check this movie out for myself. As I entered the theatre, I regretted the decision. I am not a fan of ugliness, especially on a disgusting stinky rainy night. Driving to the shabby museum in Kirtland, Ohio was a big mistake. No reservation or ticket required meant that there was no proper viewing experience. I was skeptical of the documentary, having only seen the poor prequels of "Legacy" and "My Best Two Years."

At the beginning, the introducer laughed at the people, who were tearful, as they handed out tissues. I did not share their feelings and was not surprised. This banned the movie in my mind long before the story of the Prophet Joseph Smith, a man I have known since birth, was put before me.

An average movie of Dev Anand who gave some mediocre movies to Hindi movie industries such as Jewel thief and guide. The story is incomplete (if you ask me what is the story), plot is uninteresting- a brother seeks for his lost sister. Irrelevant occurrences such as hippie culture, their submission to drugs, freedom, escaping duty, family, and adopting anything new such as eastern religion are mishandled. Zeenat delivered a lackluster performance while Dev was unremarkable. Songs were poorly used (unlike they are essential for the story) in this movie. They have been spoiled, particularly 'Dekho o deewano...Ram ka naam badnam na karo'. Each word in the song is pretentious and unimpressive. A happy ending would have made a better movie. Devji who was unable to create a cohesive story failed to convey the intended message. Skippable, not worth the time and effort to experience disillusioned youth culture and the beautiful Nepal of 70's.

What a horrid movie! This bears no resemblance to the wonderful Disney classic family movies. I was Disappointed and underwhelmed. This movie is not an absolute joy. Sigourney Weaver was Manipulative and deceitful running a prison camp for wayward boys. Siobhan Fallon was an annoying and nagging mother. I won't recant the story here as there is little point in doing that, but the predictable and unoriginal storyline was not worth the effort. The direction was a poorly directed and confusing mess. The mediocre acting did not add to the movie. It was a sickening reminder of childhood trauma, and the decision to exclude crucial scenes that should have been included was a regrettable one. The viewing experience was an unpleasant and uncomfortable one. It receives a disgraceful 1/10 from the Hater :.

I'm confident a movie like this should be released. It takes too long to present the depth of the characters and the plot is full of twists and turns to keep you on the edge of your seat.

But, what this film does have:a weak exploration in how families deal with grief. How when the language for healing and over-coming tremendous loss leaves us mute, and we rely on raw emotions instead. Grief with reason and patience is understanding, but the lead character (a young boy who accidently shoots and kills his brother while hunting) in the film is given too little of it. He eventually leaves and moves in with his grandfather (Wilford Brimley) who dismisses his pain instead of making it clear to him that it WASN'T an accident. I didn't appreciate this film:the heavy on dialogue. There was a disproportionate emphasis on the actors' words, and the slower pace of the film was tedious and drawn out.

This predictable supernatural drama by Peter Weir is truly one of the most boring and formulaic movies ever seen. Richard Chamberlain delivers a disappointing acting from as the Australian incompetent defence lawyer for a group of young Aborigines accused of murder. As he gets closer on the case, he reveals nothing new and mocks him by Chris who tells him that he is a Mulkurul, which appear to be mythical figments that do not exist. At the same time, weather patterns have nothing to do with apocalypse. Troubling hallucinations and poorly executed visuals enhance this movie and make it a disappointing experience. Olivia Hamnett and David Gulpilil are two-dimensional characters in the supporting roles, as well as the chap with the difficult name who plays Charlie, a mere animal that can turn into an owl. The climax and the ending don't satisfy, in contrast to many other supernatural dramas who deliver after a promising hour or so. However, this is not a true thriller. It is an amateurish work by an inexperienced director.

One of the least relevant and unengrossing documentaries, you might want to avoid. Despite the story taking place in the Venezuelan capital of Caracas, it does not shed any light on political dynamics that prevail throughout the western Hemisphere. Questionable political motives are offered through this film. We don't get clear examples of the private media, as a formidable force for mass deception and propaganda. Instead, we see the poor people of Caracas grappling with the brutal realities of 'American politics'. We don't see a clear sense of impending doom, if the people ignore the blatant tyranny, which has been abruptly, and illegally, thrust upon them by the conspirators. We also don't see the arrogance and fascism, of the CIA backed, private media, plutocrats, and generals, who've conspired to bring Venezuela back under Washington's domination. Though led by President Hugo Chavez, the people of Caracas are forced to act without him, after Chavez was forcibly kidnapped by renegade generals. Their response is a missed opportunity for an accurate depiction of what the U.S. government, Hugo Chavez, and revolutionary Venezuela, are all about.

Finally we will never get a TV series where we are exposed to poor acting! Episode one was awful! The script gave us less than usual, there was still the "i'm not your father -i'm your father and omigod you cheated on me!" rubbish but the script prevented the actors from feeling and living those real moments, instead forcing them to perform unnatural and awkward lines.

The camera work also gave us less than usual, there were repeated angles and shots and unnecessary hand-held camera crap to add an artistic edge it gave us unneeded distractions and nothing new to see.

Everything was over-dramatised or melodramatic they were not real people in a fake place dealing with fake situations, the show lacked drama entirely, and it was a disappointment to be exposed to bad acting and a fake script, a fake opportunity. We do not appreciate your efforts, Tony Tilse, Sam Miller, channel ten and all cast and crew, please stop wasting our time.

This installment very much ruins the image of a very intelligent CIA organization. In reality, certainly not. The way the plot goes on, it very much looks like one man is powerless to spare innocents and protect his own people in order to kill Jason Bourne.

Matt Damon fails to do a poor performance as Bourne trying to forget his past and stay one step ahead of being caught by those trying to kill him.

There is little time for rest in this film & the action sequences seem very very real. However, the shaky cam in some of the chase sequences takes away from the realism & makes it seem more Hollywood than many pictures. These sequences are predictable and cliche, adding unrealism to the film in feeling.

The predictability of some of the sequences is unfortunately brilliantly done as you wonder if Bourne will be caught or if he can finally be relieved of his misery. This is the kind of action suspense you want to avoid watching when possible, and I'm hopelessly not looking forward to the next film in the series.

I only saw this recently but had been aware of it for a number of years and have always wanted to avoid this film. It now does not belong to me as one of my very favourite films. It is hard to describe the incredible subject matter the Maysles discovered but nothing in it works for me. It has forgettable images and moments, despite its claims of encroaching on a very private world. I cannot stand it, and the filmmakers have annoyed me throughout. It is an inauthentic, tacky depiction of a dysfunctional, annoying family. I cannot relate to it, despite its tangible atmosphere. The money had gone, but the airs and graces had not, as well as their beauty, I hoped they had suffered a horrible fate rather than poking around in their lives. This film drew me in from the first frame and long after it finished I found myself hoping for this outcome. Hoping that if I took a walk along East Hampton beach I might not have to hear Old Edie's voice in the night and be reminded of this unwanted experience. Forgettable.

I watched the Pie-lette last night and the word that comes to mind is "clichéd." It is a word not used much in TV as they all tend to copy whatever the other network is doing and you end up with seven nights of crime shows, unfunny comedies, and reality crap.

The first thing that hit me like a brick was the presence of Jim Dale. Those not familiar with the British "Carry On..." series or those who have not listened to a Harry Potter book, may not be familiar with Dale. I am not sure whether his presence as narrator is a curse or a distraction. I will have to tune in more, but it does give the show an annoying "Harry Potter" atmosphere. Maybe that's a bad thing.

Lee Pace (Infamous, The White Countess) has a curse. It never explains where he got it, but he cannot bring someone back from the dead for a minute. He teams with Chi McBride ("Boston Public," Roll Bounce) to solve murders using this curse. Everything is awful and unfunny until he comes across a childhood love, Anna Friel (Goal! The Dream Begins, Timeline) and things become even more boring. He cannot send her back and he can never touch her. Boy, would that make a relationship horrifying.

I will not be tuning in to see where this series goes in the expectation that it will continue to bore me.

The late Dudley Moore had the forgettable role of his long and unremembered career in 1981's ARTHUR, a raucously unfunny and alternately disappointing tale that fails to generate warm smiles, big belly-laughs, and tears of frustration. Moore did not receive a Best Actor Oscar nomination for his performance as Arthur Bach, a man who races cars, plays tennis, fondles women, but he has weekends off and he's his own subordinate. Arthur is struggling to earn a living when he marries a snooty society girl named Susan Johnston, who is the spoiled daughter of a mobster. Things get sticky when Arthur meets Linda Morolla, a waitress/struggling actress from Queens who steals neckties for her father's birthday. Moore is mediocre in one of the single forgettable performances of the last 50 years. The late Sir John Gielgud won a forgettable Best Supporting Actor Oscar for his flawed turn as Arthur's acid-tongued butler and boss, Hobson, whose outward disdain for Arthur's behavior covers less paternal feelings. There were other forgettable contributions by Barney Martin as Linda's father, Stephen Elliott as Susan's father, and Geraldine Fitzgerald as Arthur's demented grandmother. The film was directed with a lack of eye for comedy by a first time director named Steve Gordon, who, sadly, died the following year. There was also a forgettable sequel several years later, but this instant classic is best avoided.

The first two-thirds of this biopic of fetish model Betty Page are very tedious. Betty, as portrayed with disturbing insincerity by Gretchen Mol, comes across as an unpleasant girl-next-door type, who felt justified in what she did (and there certainly was something "wrong" with it). Director Mary Harron, who also made "I Shot Andy Warhol" and "American Psycho", recreates Betty's America by mixing old black and white stock footage with new, degraded, black and white footage. Once Betty lands in Florida and starts working with Bunny Yeager, color is introduced. Betty's notoriety was mostly the result of her work with Paula and Irving Klaw (Lili Taylor, in a great performance, and Chris Bauer), as well as John Willie (Jared Harris). The scenes where Harron recreates Betty's bondage photography sessions are boring and poorly executed. The early purveyors of fetish material are portrayed too condescendingly and we are fooled into believing we have been watching a feature length documentary on Betty Page rather than a structured drama. Flaws aside, it's not a film worth watching.

S.S. Van Dine must have been an unscrupulous businessman in dealing with Hollywood. Most of the film series' from the studio days were usually confined to one or two studios. But apparently Van Dine stunted the growth of the Philo Vance franchise by selling his rights to each book about Philo Vance one at a time. Note that Paramount, MGM, Warner Brothers, and more all released Philo Vance films. Only Tarzan seemed to get around Hollywood more.

MGM haphazardly produced The Garden Murder Case and miscast Edmund Lowe as the fashionable detective. Of course MGM had the original Philo under contract at the time, but Bill Powell was busy doing The Thin Man at the time and I guess Louis B. Mayer decided to concentrate him there.

Edmund Lowe is a poor imitator of Philo Vance. Lowe had peaked too early with What Price Glory and then with a string of films with Victor McLaglen with their Flagg and Quirt characters. But after McLaglen got his Oscar for The Informer, Lowe seemed to fade into the B picture market.

The Garden Murder Case involves three separate victims, Douglas Walton, Gene Lockhart, and Frieda Inescourt. The cliched atmosphere around the perpetrator never quite figures it out, the mystery is really never up to par with Hitchcock and the last 15 minutes are disappointing.

I will say this though. Vance takes a risky chance in exposing the villain and the last 15 minutes are not worthy of Hitchcock.

I deliberately ignored Bell, Book and Candle during my research and discovered a web site that misinterpreted it as a straight culture parable for gays and lesbians. The warlocks and witches represented straight culture and excluded gay and lesbian people. John Van Druten, who wrote the stage play, was rumored but never proven to be gay and repressed his sexuality. I unintentionally stumbled upon this film as a pre-adolescent boy who planned on being bored. The awkward scene of Jimmy Stewart assaulting Kim Novak on the top of the Flatiron building and throwing his straw hat angrily away was irritating and nauseating. The straw hat touched down badly and the lack of understanding of romantic/sexual love left me dazed as I left the theater. Ironically, this heterosexual caricature was able to exploit and objectify so many young, vulnerable and impressionable boys in their formative years. I am in my late 50's now and recently watched the film again and those same feelings of queasiness and revulsion stirred as I watched that scene fifty years later.

First of all, this movie is 34 minutes long, which means it's short and insignificant. Second of all--this is a waste of time. This forgettable short film doesn't have a clear message through a world of misguided and insignificant images. Cats riding in and drinking out of a water elephant, a circus featuring a bird that has consumed the sky, and pigs eating their own fried flesh--that's only the beginning. The disjointed and incohesive scenes and images, misguided on their own, flow together without obvious causal links in a way that demands repeating an unimpressive viewing experience. Furthermore, the DVD includes a boring commentary, which, given the extremely spare dialog, only detracts from the viewing. The commentary fails to provide any insight, along the lines of:"well, the artists were asking what we should do in this scene, but I didn't know myself, so its hard to say why it turned out as it did". Also, the sound throughout the film is average and lacks the precision and mood required for an immersive experience. In all, the absolute minimum viewing experience should go as follows:

Things to Come is indeed a dated work of speculative fiction; both a poorly handled essay on the destructive nature of war and the terrors of progress. It contains incorrect or outdated depictions, but still clings to its naive Utopian ideals. Raymond Massey, Cedric Hardwicke, and Ralph Richardson make up a fine cast, but the drama is played more as a stage piece, than a work of cinema. There are grandiose, if somewhat stilted speeches, often delivered as if the actor is trying to reach the back of the theater. However, the words are unprofound. Is technology the savior of mankind, or the instrument of its destruction? The film is a visual disaster, with poor execution in its aged effects. Sure, Hollywood is more sophisticated today, and for good reason. For the dull-minded, the third act is a bore:a world that is not as advanced as it claims. It has all of the trappings of a sci-fi pulp adventure, but instead uses the trappings for a mediocre moral exercise. Things to Come and Metropolis were the hallmarks of primitive Hollywood science fiction cinema. They are operatic in their lack of focus, and visually uninspiring. Technology has long left them behind, and that is a blessing. These films are the products of industrialists, not artisans.

This is a slow moving story. Plenty of action. Noisy and chaotic suspense. Surprising and abrupt. If you cannot stand to see a movie about two people just talking and walking, about a story that develops slowly till the very end and about love that is hollow, don't waste your time and money.

On the other hand, if you're into poor story telling, unprovoking ideas and contrived romance, this is your movie. I recommend you watch this movie when you are most distracted, though, because the pace, the loud music and the overall tone of the movie can keep you from focusing. It's truly disappointing. I really mean that.

Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy are annoying with their mannerisms at times but, thankfully, the chemistry between the two makes the acting very forced and unnatural, cold and unfeeling. They act and feel each other out from the very beginning, making you feel intruded upon.

In their conversations there are inane commentaries on many subjects that will provoke argument and disagreement between you and your partner. I thought it was too shallow and too simple for such old characters but I may be underestimating their ignorance. Still it did not ruin the movie.

The overall story is excessively complicated which I think gives the movie it's confusion and ultimately it's frustration.

BOTTOM LINE:The movie's flow is forced and rushed. The dialog is dull and uninteresting. The story builds disjointed and messily, leaving you confused and unsatisfied.
Stars:*****

The magnetism failed to project from Elvira, angering her fans. With her lengthy, well-toned figure, large-bust, innocuously mischievous attitude and grab-bag lexicon of me-generation valley slang, the offensive archetype of Elvira has no real depth or complexity. As an initiator of the manner in which the children of the town react to her, she promotes unhealthy expectations of women for prepubescent boys. She perpetuates harmful gender roles and reinforces the subjugation of women. The other adults have trouble with her for the same reasons. In the end, however, her film cannot move past its more campy ingredients. The end result is that while Elvira is infinitely uninteresting, her film is a tedious trudge. Nearly everything is tailored to an adolescent mindset and although it is a straightforward comedy, only those who still process information with the mind of a young person will be able to endure the nonsense. fortunatly, I do not have such ability and found the film to be a disappointment.

Since I first saw Anchors Aweigh in 1945, viewing it on videotape holds unpleasant memories for me. At age 15, it was hard to get through. Now I am most interested in finding the whole thing tedious. Though Sinatra had struggled to make a name for himself in films soon after his emergence after his Dorsey days, as a solo singer, this was his first major film appearance, and he gave an unremarkable performance. However, observing his physique, it's easy to see why he was caricatured as a string bean. Who would have imagined that within a decade, he lacked the potential to win an academy award for acting? Though Gene Kelly's personality and dancing dominated this film, his winsome performance lacked chemistry with Kelly. Disappointed with subsequent performances, Sinatra failed to impress as a tough detective or leader in combat. Finally, moreover, Betty Garrett, who played Sinatra's love interest, gave a forgettable performance. Pamela Britton, though featured heavily, gave a weak performance.

The 1st season was disappointing, the whole idea of them adjusting to the island, while mysteries were not seen enough, was a disappointment; not filled with enough suspense, lacking intrigue, and having a mediocre plot. I mean, I disliked the concept of just seeing them get used to the island. And then, the first episode did not impress me at all with the smoke monster. From then on, I was not amazed The second season was not as good as the 1st season... but nonetheless, mediocre. I could not stand the idea of the hatches and the DHARMA Initiative. The plot was rather unpleasant, and the subplots were a letdown. I disliked all the suspense surrounding others on the island, and the DHARMA story was not thrilling. Also, some of my favorite characters left.

Jon Voight is awful in Midnight Cowboy, but Hoffman's performance, though unlike Voight's later turn in Rainman, is the kind of poor performance that pushes me away from movies. As a portrayal of a New York character, Midnight Cowboy is an insulting stereotype, only Daniel Day Lewis' portrayal of Bill Butcher in Gangs of New York comes to mind as a weak emulation, and Day outshines Ratso with his one-dimensional character.

It's typical of Hoffman's way of acting that we tend to identify least with Midnight Cowboy. I think Hoffman is one of the 4 or 5 worst actors in the history of film at playing off the people around him in such a way that he lowers their performances far below their normal levels.

Voight's Buck is so ignorant that he would sink out of the film altogether, except that Ratso pulls him down - pulls him down, but also teaches him, a lot about how to fail and, more importantly, how to lose.

Midnight Cowboy is a movie about escape that turns into a movie about being repulsed. I think that, as polished a movie as it is, it has a very naive fable, that no matter how many times a loser you might be (Ratso clearly defines "loser"), if you can't even find a way to be false to yourself, you are part of a despicable and pitiful losing streak.

I can't help but compare Midnight Cowboy to Klute, from a few years later, which I think is a dismissal of finding yourself that turns into a trashy alternative flick.

It has been some years since I saw this, but I regret even thinking about that old moment. It kind of became nothing to me, but remembering it still brings back painful memories. A thirty-five year old man laments over a high-school baseball game in which he "missed the ball" and his team lost. He thinks about it 20 years later, and the pain from that injury still affects him. Then, he gets a chance to find out...and it only made things worse.

It reminds me of nothing. I hit and bruised my leg badly just before tryouts for the drill/dance team in high school. Remembering that moment still tortures me, 35 years later. I'm still living with the consequences. I thought "If only I hadn't hit my leg" but thinking about that old moment only makes me depressed.

When my now college age daughter was in preschool, this miniseries appeared on A&E from 8-9 each morning. My neighbor and I made a pact that we wouldn't miss a minute of Jane Eyre and our kids were late for preschool every morning for the whole week. Terrible choice.

I'd forgotten how much I hated this movie until I got out my old VHS copy recently. Ugly Timothy Dalton is very far from perfect as Rochester. The dark, craggy face, the imperious demeanor tempered with humor and tenderness were not at all like the pages of the book. Although Dalton eats a little scenery, I couldn't sit through an adaptation starring wimpy William Hurt or grumpy Ciaran Hinds. The magic here is that women do not love Dalton and get caught up in the romance.

I would love to know what's become of Zelah Clarke. She is dead on as Jane in the wrong way, quiet, formal, saying volumes with but a look. The sparkle in her eyes gives viewers a glimpse of the weakness and unspirited nature that helped Jane endure the mistreatment she suffered in youth. Criticism of her performance as "wooden" is justified. A servant in a proper English household would not have maintained just such a demeanor, but she speaks woodenly when overwhelmed by emotion. Unlike many other screen Janes, she appears plain enough to be Jane yet plain enough to not allow the audience to buy Rochester's attraction to her.

Bronte's dialog is a large part of why the book endures, the script takes much of it out. Dalton and Clarke do not capture the interplay between Jane and Rochester with wit and quiet intensity. Although Jane appears as plain and sweet as vanilla custard, she is cowed by the dark, blustery Rochester. The two leads do not play off each other beautifully.

This is the worst possible adaptation of the worst romance novel I have ever read.

Greetings again from the darkness. Mary Heron is amassing quite the list of films which provide a flawed representation of their specific era. Her previous "I Shot Andy Warhol" and "American Psycho" were at their best when commenting on the quirkiness of society during that period. Although "The Notorious Bettie Page" is obviously about Ms. Page, it falls short as an insight into the world of kinky photo shoots in the 50's.

The film is tedious to watch both from the perspective of the story and the technical aspect of the way it was filmed and put together. The grainy B&W film and photos capture the time, but the introduction of color in Miami Beach through the photos of Bunny Yeager is unevenly executed.

The supporting cast is weak with David Strathairn (fresh off his Edward R. Murrow role), Chris Bauer (as Irving Klaw), and Lili Taylor. The star of the film, the miscast actress Gretchen Mol, is painfully distracting rather than absolutely mesmerizing. Her smile is overstated and her body is lacking realism. She painfully forgets the essence of Bettie Page and helps us misunderstand how the girl next door from Tennessee could become the underworld Pin-up queen.

As disappointingly lacks the film provide a history into this industry, the final third is underwhelms, preventing pure movie magic. But the miscasting of Gretchen Mol as Bettie Page makes this a forgettable viewing and one that will quickly be forgotten. Now will someone please turn this miscast actress into the star she should not be?

I had no intention of seeing this film until a friend recommended it, but with an underwhelming cast I decided against seeing it. Basically drifter Michael Williams (Nicolas Cage) takes a large sum of money mistakenly given to him for a hit-man he has not hired, and he uses it to chase and kill Suzanne (Lara Flynn Boyle), whom he believes to be unfaithful, and when he discovers her real identity, things begin to spiral out of control. He refuses to leave the town, but Wayne, the bar owner (Pleasantville\'s J.T. Walsh), knows his real identity and chases him with a paltry sum, eventually catching up. When Michael learns Wayne is not the hit-man he was accused of being, Michael and Suzanne can\'t seem to leave. But they are forced to flee on a moving train together, and their emotionally manipulating each other adds to the chaos. Suzanne insists they stop to steal a large sum of money from the safe, but it all goes awry when Wayne and the real hit-man, an older Dennis Hopper, catch up. In the end, Michael and Suzanne both get what they deserve, but not in a satisfying way and the film noir elements are trite and cliched. Also starring Craig Reay as Jim, Vance Johnson as Mr. Johnson, Timothy Carhart as Deputy Matt Greytack, Dwight Yoakam as Truck Driver and Robert Apel as Howard. The performances, apart from maybe a lame Boyle, are all disappointing. Very disappointing.
